The proud people of Argentina look up to you, Julio Roca, president and great lieutenant. Lead your nation to glory by defeating the enemies that dare stand in your borders, as you expand the land and might of Argentina. Make use of the colonial Estancias to feed and empower your people, as well as strategic points in your conquests. You are called to bring Argentina to a new age of glory above your neighbors. Should you succeed, great Julio Argentino Roca, your people will forever remember you.
Well met. I'm Julio Argentino Roca. Yes, my second name is in fact Argentino, and I proudly live with it, and honour it and my nation with conquest and progress. And you are?
Just here there's an Estancia with some top-quality meat for us to enjoy, care to join us as civilized folk?
I'm most grateful.
Let us exchange information on our capitals for the mutual growth of our people.
Your visit is welcome, as long as you don't come near my lands.
Fine.
No.
I have sent my troops with some meat and books from Argentina, to feed our stomachs and our progress. Will you accept or are you just a barbarian?
I accept your request.
These lands are beautiful, not for uncivilized folk such as you.
Don't make me regret this offer.
Excellent.
I'm afraid I can't accept your proposal.
Your people are civilized. Argentina could benefit from a Friendship with you.
I accept.
Pffft.
Let us form an alliance to destroy the uncivilized barbarians around us!
You're an example to follow, truly you have progressed far.
I warn you, I kill any uncivilized barbarian that threatens my rightful lands!
My troops are ready to destroy your troops near my borders. Leave.

Roca's Argentina is more military oriented than that of Evita's. With the Estancias as a strong option in early game Roca can focus on expanding and defending his territory while strengthening his culture.

Roca is a strong leader and a powerful enemy. Be careful when dealing against his troops on the borders, for that is his primary way of expansion. Playing Roca allows for strong turtling strategies while building up culture and Musicians for Argentina.
Julio Argentino Roca (1843-1914) was an Argentine general and the leader of the oligarchy that held political control of Argentina from 1880 to 1916. He was a typical 19th-century caudillo.

Julio Roca was born of a prominent and wealthy Argentine family in Tucumán on July 17, 1843. He received a degree from the National College in Uruguay. When he was approximately fifteen, he volunteered to fight for the interior provinces in the struggle against the forces of Buenos Aires and was commissioned a sublieutenant; thereafter he remained on the military rolls for a period of 55 years of continuous service.

Upon the death of the secretary of war, Adolfo Alsino, Roca undertook a successful campaign against the Indians in the south and added extensive land to the national domain, most of which fell into his and his friends' hands. Also, the Indian captives were to all intents and purposes forced into slavery under the application of old colonial laws. The results of the successful campaign made Roca popular in powerful circles, and he was elected president in 1880.

Roca's administration ushered in a period of Argentine history known as the "era of the oligarchy," which lasted until 1916. Its core was made up of the great landowners, and it exerted its power through what has been called the most powerful farmers' organization in the Western Hemisphere, plus certain commercial elements with close ties with the British. On the credit side of the ledger, his government was powerful enough to end the many years of political chaos which had preceded his assumption of office.
